Today, we continue our look at the African-American literary imagination with a trip into uncharted territory.

Among those who have, Octavia Butler.
When she died early last year, she was among the best-known contemporary science fiction writer, black or otherwise.
But she told NPR's Terry Gross in 1993 that her race didn't factor into her book sales, until she started writing about it.
When I got into science fiction, I sold my first three books without an agent and with no particular connections.
I just mailed them in over the transom.
So nobody knew who I was and nobody knew I was black, and no one - apparently, there wasn't any worrying.
I didn't have any difficulty selling my first three novels.
When I wrote ""Kindred,"" which is unmistakably of special interest to black people, I had a lot of trouble.
All of a sudden, 15 publishers couldn't find a place for it.
They just had no idea how to sell it as what it was.
Kindred"" is a novel set in 1976 about a woman who is transported back to the days of American slavery.
